Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Subspace Matching and Approximation on the Continuum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In a diverse range of application areas--including astronomical
imaging, microscopy, wireless communications, radar, sonar, and
many others--one must confront the problem of estimating or
extracting information from a signal that is governed by a small
number of unknown (continuous-valued) parameters. Customized to
each of these applications, unique methods for handling these
unknown parameters have been proposed in the past. This research
involves the development of a unified framework for addressing
problems in all of these areas systematically, efficiently, with
awareness of the fundamental limits, and with provable accuracy.

There are two main components of this framework. The first
component involves the development of models where the signals of
interest lie within or close to a subspace or a union of subspaces.
In the case where the underlying parameters for the signal are
continuous-valued, this is a challenging task. Rather than attempt
to simply discredit these problems (a program potentially fraught
with difficulty), this research involves the development of finite
approximations for a locally infinite range of subspaces using
efficient local subspace fits whose dimensions match the effective
number of local degrees of freedom. The second component of this
framework consists of techniques for identifying the range of
subspaces responsible for generating a signal from a set of
discrete observations, confronting difficulties posed by the
coherence, by the continuous nature of the parameter space, and by
the fact that some signals may be synthesized from a narrow (but
continuously-indexed and therefore infinite) range of subspaces.
These components combine to enable the efficient acquisition,
processing, and estimation of signals arising from the
parameterized subspaces model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a diverse range of signal processing application areas--including astronomical imaging, microscopy, wireless communications, radar, sonar, and many others--one must confront the problem of estimating or extracting information from a signal that is governed by a small number of unknown parameters. This project involved the development of a unified framework for addressing such problems systematically, efficiently, with awareness of the fundamental limits, and with provable accuracy. In particular, this project involved reconciling two competing points of view: (1) First, the information in a signal of interest can often be captured using a low-dimensional subspace model. Such models are ubiquitous in classical “least-squares” signal processing, and they enable the removal of noise and the recovery of missing information. All of this is made possible by the fact that the subspace dimension is lower than the signal dimension. (2) Second, however, in applications such as those listed above, the question of which subspace model is the right one for a particular signal depends on one or more continuously-valued parameters. In other words, there are an infinite number of possible subspace models, which conflicts with the benefits afforded by the low dimension of each model.

As a platform for studying such problems, an ongoing case study in this project examined a collection of signals known as the Discrete Prolate Spheroidal Sequences (DPSS’s). These functions have important properties in terms of their time-frequency concentration, and they are useful for localizing parameters such as object positions or carrier frequencies when only limited signal samples are available. New multiband dictionaries of DPSS’s were constructed, and the abilities of such dictionaries to represent certain signal families were studied theoretically. These dictionaries were used for improving target detection and removing wall clutter in through-the-wall radar imaging problems. The resulting algorithms can handle reverberations from the wall return using cancelation relative to a subspace spanned by the columns of a narrowband DPSS dictionary. The extended (nonpoint) targets are then identified sequentially in a greedy algorithm, where a local DPSS-like dictionary is constructed to capture the unknown target return in an extended spatial region around the point of interest, the return is canceled relative to this subspace, and the algorithm proceeds to identify the next target. To facilitate computations with DPSS’s, two versions of a Fast Slepian Transform (so-named because DPSS’s were originally studied by David Slepian and others) were developed. Also, as a more powerful and precise alternative to the greedy algorithm described above, atomic norm minimization was employed for solving multipath imaging and multiband frequency localization problems. 

To better understand the fundamental capabilities and limits in such parameterized subspace problems, this project also involved a detailed study of the structured matrices that arise in these problems. New results were developed to characterize the asymptotic equivalence of Toeplitz matrices and certain circulant approximations, in terms of the individual asymptotic convergence of the eigenvalues. Also, generalizing the combined time- and band-limiting operations that appear in DPSS problems, the similarities between the spectrum of an infinite Toeplitz operator and its time-limited counterpart (e.g., a matrix) were studied. The answers to such questions help provide new insight into the effective dimensionality of certain signal families (such as the class of signals that are time-limited and essentially band-limited) and the amount of information that can be transmitted in space or time by band-limited functions.

An additional research component of this project involved the use of low-rank (low-dimensional subspace) models for accelerating certain matrix-valued nonconvex optimization problems. In particular, the geometric landscape of such problems was characterized, resulting in the identification of favorable classes of machine learning problems where simple iterative algorithms can converge to a globally optimal solution. 

On the educational side, this project supported the training and education of Graduate Research Assistants and led to the development of a new, required Electrical Engineering course at the Colorado School of Mines. This class focuses on introducing students to topics in probability and statistics, with applications specific to topics in Electrical Engineering. The course also allows for one lecture per week to be replaced with a problem-solving session where students use laptops to answer questions from an online quiz database. The questions are multiple choice (and therefore machine gradeable) and have both high-level and detailed solutions so the students can get timely feedback on their work. Students must answer a free-response question before they are shown the multiple choice options. Working in coordination with collaborators at Georgia Tech, the PI at Mines developed fill-in-the-blank lecture notes, contributed questions to the quiz database, and developed an implementation of the quizzes in the Canvas platform to facilitate sharing with other institutions.
